{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3549783,"name":"Nana","username":"nado","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/71e660/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T21:05:27.103Z","cooked":"

Hi, wierd question:
How can i use simple images in onshape. For exemple a heart icon that i want to extrude cut in a part.

I tried to convert the image to dxf and it worked but i couldn’t edit the sketch

Try converting images to .step files, here’s a decent converter: Convert JPG to STEP for free - ImageToStl from here, you should be able to insert the file and extrude the sketch/ profile create from the image.

(or you could just y’know sketch half of it and mirror… lol)

I’ve run into similar issues in Inventor for years, you can import images but you can’t extrude them, and most of the image to solid conversion tools have all kinds of limitations (though I haven’t tried that one linked above yet).

One solution I found for this in Inventor is if you have simple B/W images you can actually convert them a custom Font, load that on your PC and then and then use the Text tool in inventor sketches to pull the image in as a font, then extrude it. Not sure if Onshape has something similar, but it’s a workaround that’s worked for me.

Images can be converted to DXF files with surprising accuracy. It depends on what the icon is, but it can work.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-28T01:08:45.635Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":198,"readers_count":197,"score":54.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494536,"topic_slug":"images-in-cad","display_username":"Calvin Selin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69303,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design Minion/Creative Scouter"},"post_url":"/t/images-in-cad/494536/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605694,"name":"Ryan Reed","username":"Ryan_Reed","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7feea3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-28T03:45:55.802Z","cooked":"

I think importing the image and tracing it manually can be a good solution for simple stuff, but for more complicated stuff I recommend using Inkscape. It’s free and pretty powerful for vector graphics, including trace functionality. If you want something quick and easy, I recommend importing an image, using the “trace bitmap” feature, then simplifying with Path->Simplify so your CAD software doesn’t have a stroke. I recommend turning down the “Simplification Threshold” in settings, its too aggressive out of the box. Try to finalize the art before importing because it can be difficult to edit in CAD since nothing is dimensioned. Strategically fixing points and lines on the sketch can help a lot when trying to make changes after importing.

There’s definitely a learning curve, but I think its a valuable tool for both art and CAD. I’ve used it to convert manufacturer’s drawings from a PDF to DXF to then import into CAD when they don’t provide a STEP, to design merch, processing files for laser cutting, and probably more I can’t think of right now.
